climbs.name: Kung-Fu Panda
climbs.fa: Adam Tutte '14 FA Patrick Thomas Waddington '15

content.description:
A Bear Cave, KLO Creek and Kelowna area must do!

This climb features super cool movement, a beta intensive crux section (lots of options), sustained climbing, and good clean rock!

Start out by climbing up easy terrain through clipping the 5th perma from below (I count the old draw at the bottom as a perma). Take a final shake out even though you haven't burned anything yet and drop the hammer until you clip the last perma (#8) and clear the lip.

Perma #6 can be a bit tricky to clip, but all falls after first 5 permas should be clean even if you blow a clip. No individual move is ripper hard, but it is tenuous, sequencey, sustained, and really easy to botch! Run out from perma 8 to the chains in easy (5.8) terrain. if you somehow blew the chains I don't think you would hit the ground, but probably not a great idea to test that theory either. 

If you opt for a knee pad, throw it on your right leg.

Second line from the left. The first line is somewhat difficult to spot, Kung-Fu Panda is the first line of perma-draws
8 permas, 2 bolt anchor with a locking steal biner.

A boulder problem off the starting ledge, followed by the hardest 5.11 climbing of your life.

This climb starts in the bush on the far right of Bear Cave (just right of the actual cave). There is a super low bolt, just above the belay chain. Make sure you clip this, it's for your belayer- not for you. The second bolt is a perma and protects the powerful boulder problem crux which seems to involve an undercling, body tension, a lot of power and a little bit of desperation to turn the lip. Clip bolt 3 when you can, and get out of there!

Much easier, but cryptic climbing from bolt 4 until your last bolt. Slightly run out low 5th climbing from the last bolt to the chains. Long-draw bolt 5.

Knee pad on your left if you want it, but it's more than likely your blood pressure will be high enough that you won't notice the rock stabbing into the end of your thigh.

Look for the belay chain right (east) of the true cave. 
6(?) bolts, 2 permas, 2 bolt anchor with fixed biners.

Climbs from 5.11b to 5.14. Several climbs start out of a deep cave and feature burly boulders lower down, all climbs are overhanging at some point! This wall is home of "Kung-Fu Panda", one of the premier lines in the park. This sector is "L" shaped, with faces to the south and east- morning sun and a shade line that sweeps from left to right on the wall starting late morning.  
  
 For this sector, you can get away with a 60 m rope and ~10 quick draws. Most routes have chains with fixed biners. As with other sectors, be prepared to thread your rope as sometimes the screw-gates get jammed shut.
